BALLOTPEDIA
On Monday, the court will hear Janus v. AFSCME, a public unions case that could finally resolve a union fees issue that the court has struggled to address several times in the last few years. The issue in Janus is whether the Supreme Court should overrule its 1977 decision in Abood v. Detroit Board of Education that public sector employees can be required to pay agency fees. The plaintiff in this case is Mark Janus, a public sector employee in Illinois. Janus challenged an Illinois statute requiring public sector employees to pay agency fees.

The court has already ruled in Abood.  It could possibly further restrict the uses of payments to recover collective bargaining fees of non-union employees but it is unlikely to substantially change the Abood decision that the collection is constitutional.  The Abood decision was unanimous.

If the Court decides against the union then it must also decide that requiring the union to negotiate for non-union members is also unconstitutional.

But the language of the above question requires that the finding be that any mandatory agency fee by non-union members be found unconstitutional.  Based on oral arguments in Friedrichs, not all of the justices that might be expected to be troubled by Abood would necessarily favor completely overturning a public employer’s ability to use a mechanism that private employers use.  In orals, counsel for Friedrichs acknowledged that a public employer could pay a union’s agency fees directly, rather than the more convoluted system of paying employees and then deducting agency fees from payroll.  While I expect that a slim majority are troubled enough by Abood to seek to amend and curtail it, it is possible that will not result in making any and all mandatory agency fees unconstitutional.  I assess the likelihood of an amendment and/or curtailment of Abood at 80%, if so, the likelihood of total abolition of mandatory agency fees by public employers 75%.
